spectraltools.io.parse_csv module

class spectraltools.io.parse_csv.Spectra(ordinates: numpy.ndarray[typing.Any, numpy.dtype[+ScalarType]], spectra: numpy.ndarray[typing.Any, numpy.dtype[+ScalarType]], sample_names: list[str])

Bases: object

ordinates: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]
sample_names: list[str]
spectra: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]
spectraltools.io.parse_csv.read_csv(csv_file: Union[Path, str], csv_order: int = 1) → Spectra

Gather up wavelengths, spectral data and spectra names from a csv file. This is just a small wrapper around a pandas read_csv

Parameters

  • csv_file (Union[Path, str]) – pathlib Path to csv file or string literal to file

  • csv_order (int, optional) – 1 = wavelength first column, 0 = wavelength first row. Defaults to 1.

Returns

Spectra class

Return type

Spectra

spectraltools.io.parse_envi module

class spectraltools.io.parse_envi.Spectra(ordinates: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], spectra: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], header_info: dict)

Bases: object

Data returned from calling read_envi. Contains the spectral data, the ordinates and the header file information.

header_info: dict
ordinates: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]
spectra: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]
spectraltools.io.parse_envi.read_envi(envi_datafile: Union[Path, str], envi_hdrfile: Union[Path, str]) → Spectra

Read an envi spectral file. An ENVI file has a binary file and an accompanying .hdr file

Parameters

  • envi_datafile – pathlib Path or string literal of the envi binary files

  • envi_hdrfile – pathlib Path or string literal of the header file for the above

Returns

A class containing the ordinates, spectra and data contained in the header file

spectraltools.io.parse_numpy module

class spectraltools.io.parse_numpy.Spectra(ordinates: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], spectra: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]])

Bases: object

Data from calling read_numpy. Its a bit naff really as its already in a numpy format and all this will do is stick it into this class so its together. Cant really see this being of much use.

ordinates: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]
spectra: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]
spectraltools.io.parse_numpy.read_numpy(numpy_ordinates: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]], numpy_spectra: ndarray[Any, dtype[ScalarType]]) → Spectra

Take 2 numpy arrays of ordinates and spectral data and drop them into a class containing…. wait for it, 2 numpy arrays :) This is a dumb one that really is not needed

Parameters

  • numpy_ordinates (NDArray) – ordinates of the spectral data [#bands]

  • numpy_spectra (NDArray) – the spectral data, 1D [#bands], 2D [N, #bands], 3D [N, M, #bands]

Returns

A class containing both things in one class. Wow!!

Return type

Spectra
